<TITLE>
HISTORY OF BASKETBALL
</TITLE>
<BODY>
<H1><center>HISTORY OF BASKETBALL</H1>
<h1><center>WHERE BASKETBALL ORIGINATED?</h1>
<IMG SRC="data:image/jpeg;base64," WIDTH="50%" HEIGHT="350" ALIGN="center">
<H2> <P>There’s been some confusion over the precise nature of the official relationship between Springfield College and the YMCA, as it relates to James Naismith and the invention of basketball.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>The confusion stems in part from changes in the School’s name in its early history.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> Originally the School for Christian Workers, the School early in its history had three other names which included “YMCA”: the YMCA Training School, the International YMCA Training School, and, later still, the International YMCA College.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> The College didn’t officially adopt the name “Springfield College” until 1954, even though it had been known informally as “Springfield College” for many years.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>But by whatever name, since its founding in 1885 Springfield College has always been a private and independent institution.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> The College has enjoyed a long and productive collaboration with the YMCA, but has never had any formal organizational ties to the YMCA movement.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>The confusion has been compounded by a small sign on the corner of the building where basketball was invented.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> The building stood at the corner of State and Sherman streets in Springfield, Massachusetts.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> The sign, carrying the words “Armory Hill Young Men’s Christian Association,” is visible in old photographs of the building that have circulated online.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> This has led some to believe, erroneously, that the Armory Hill YMCA owned the building, and that James Naismith was an employee of the YMCA. </P> </H2>
<H1><center>THE PERSON WHO INVENTED BASKETBALL </H1>
<IMG SRC="data:image/jpeg;base64," WIDTH="50%" HEIGHT="350" ALIGN="center">
<H2> <P>The instructor of this class was James Naismith, a 31-year-old graduate student.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> After graduating from Presbyterian College in Montreal with a theology degree, Naismith embraced his love of athletics and headed to Springfield to study physical education—at that time.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> A relatively new and unknown academic discipline—under Luther Halsey Gulick, superintendent of physical education at the College and today renowned as the father of physical education and recreation in the United States.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>As Naismith, a second-year graduate student who had been named to the teaching faculty, looked at his class, his mind flashed to the summer session of 1891, when Gulick introduced a new course in the psychology of play.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> In class discussions, Gulick had stressed the need for a new indoor game, one “that would be interesting, easy to learn, and easy to play in the winter and by artificial light.”</p> </h2> <h2> <p> No one in the class had followed up on Gulick’s challenge to invent such a game.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> But now, faced with the end of the fall sports season and students dreading the mandatory and dull required gymnasium work, Naismith had a new motivation.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>Two instructors had already tried and failed to devise activities that would interest the young men.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> The faculty had met to discuss what was becoming a persistent problem with the class’s unbridled energy and disinterest in required work.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>During the meeting, Naismith later wrote that he had expressed his opinion that “the trouble is not with the men, but with the system that we are using.”</p> </h2> <h2> <p> He felt that the kind of work needed to motivate and inspire the young men he faced “should be of a recreative nature, something that would appeal to their play instincts.”</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>Before the end of the faculty meeting, Gulick placed the problem squarely in Naismith’s lap.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>“Naismith,” he said. “I want you to take that class and see what you can do with it.”</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>So Naismith went to work, Naismith drew up the 13 original rules, which described, among other facets, the method of moving the ball and what constituted a foul.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> A referee was appointed. The game would be divided into two, 15-minute halves with a five-minute resting period in between. Naismith’s secretary typed up the rules and tacked them on the bulletin board.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> A short time later, the gym class met, and the teams were chosen with three centers, three forwards, and three guards per side. Two of the centers met at mid-court, Naismith tossed the ball, and the game of “basket ball” was born.</P> </H2>
<H1><center> NBA BASKETBALL </H1>
<IMG SRC="https://cdn.phenompeople.com/CareerConnectResources/NBANBAUS/social/1024x512-1670500646586.jpg" WIDTH="50%" HEIGHT="350" ALIGN="center">
<H2> <P>The NBA is a 77-year-old organization born from innovation.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> It was June 1946 in New York City when Boston Garden owner Walter Brown realized that major ice hockey arenas, which were vacant most nights, could be used to host basketball games.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> He established the Basketball Association of America, which in 1949 merged with the National Basketball League to create the National Basketball Association.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>The NBA has a rich tradition of game-changing plays and storied rivalries, personal sagas and team dynasties.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> Players and fans alike share the excitement of reliving key moments in basketball history, and admiring the excellence of former players, coaches and teams who helped shape the game.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> The league is home to living legends, and we honor their achievements while also looking to the future.</p> </h2>


<h2> <p>Today, the NBA is the most innovative league in sports, helping drive the growth of the game around the globe.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> We're pioneers in using technology to deliver content to fans over all forms of media, and a leader in social responsibility and community development.</p> </h2>


<h2> <p>We're preparing the league’s rising stars and staff in the NBA G League, our official minor league. Further, we're growing and expanding our Jr.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> NBA programs to get kids playing basketball and to nurture a love of the game and its values.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> Through our NBA Cares program, we're building places where families can live, learn and play.</P> </h2>
 <H1><center>THE EARLY YEARS </H1>
<IMG SRC="https://cdn.britannica.com/76/60176-050-018D3ECA/Players-peach-basket-basketball-game-1892.jpg?w=300" WIDTH="50%" HEIGHT="500" ALIGN="center">
<H2> <P>In the early years the number of players on a team varied according to the number in the class and the size of the playing area.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> In 1894 teams began to play with five on a side when the playing area was less than 1,800 square feet (167.2 square metres);</p> </h2> <h2> <p> the number rose to seven when the gymnasium measured from 1,800 to 3,600 square feet (334.5 square metres) and up to nine when the playing area exceeded that.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> In 1895 the number was occasionally set at five by mutual consent; the rules stipulated five players two years later, and this number has remained ever since.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>Since Naismith and five of his original players were Canadians, it is not surprising that Canada was the first country outside the United States to play the game.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> Basketball was introduced in France in 1893, in England in 1894, in Australia, China, and India soon thereafter, and in Japan in 1900.</p> </h2>

<h2> <p>While basketball helped swell the membership of YMCAs because of the availability of their gyms, within five years the game was outlawed by various associations because gyms that had been occupied by classes of 50 or 60 members were now monopolized by only 10 to 18 players.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> The banishment of the game induced many members to terminate their YMCA membership and to hire halls to play the game, thus paving the way to the professionalization of the sport.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>Originally, players wore one of three styles of uniforms: knee-length football trousers; jersey tights, as commonly worn by wrestlers; or short padded pants, forerunners of today’s uniforms, plus knee guards.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> The courts often were of irregular shape with occasional obstructions such as pillars, stairways, or offices that interfered with play.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> In 1903 it was ruled that all boundary lines must be straight.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> In 1893 the Narragansett Machinery Co. of Providence, Rhode Island, marketed a hoop of iron with a hammock style of basket.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> Originally a ladder, then a pole, and finally a chain fastened to the bottom of the net was used to retrieve a ball after a goal had been scored.</p> </h2> <h2> <p> Nets open at the bottom were adopted in 1912–13. In 1895–96 the points for making a basket (goal, or field goal) were reduced from three to two, and the points for making a free throw (shot uncontested from a line in front of the basket after a foul had been committed) were reduced from three to one.</p> </h2>
<p> </p>
<h1><center>NAISMITH ORIGINAL RULES </H1>
<img src="https://i.natgeofe.com/n/6c6795b0-2cbc-472c-95d6-8a54db801e47/2E0NNDH.jpg" width="50%" height="350" align="center">
<h2> <p>-The ball may be thrown in any direction with one or both hands.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-The ball may be batted in any direction with one or both hands.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-A player cannot run with the ball, the player must throw it from the spot on which he catches it, allowance to be made for a man who catches the ball when running at good speed.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-The ball must be held in or between the hands, the arms or body must not be used for holding it.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-No shouldering, holding, pushing, tripping or striking in any way the person of an opponent shall be allowed. The first infringement of this rule by any person shall count as a foul, the second shall disqualify him until the next goal is made, or if there was evident intent to injure the person, for the whole of the game, no substitute.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-A foul is striking the ball with the fist, violation of rules 3 and 4, and such as described in rule 5.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-If either side makes three consecutive fouls it shall count a goal for opponents.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-A goal shall be made when the ball is thrown or batted from grounds into the basket and stays there. If the ball rests on the edge and the opponent moves the basket it shall count as a goal.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-When the ball goes out of bounds it shall be thrown into the field and played by the person first touching it. In case of a dispute, the umpire shall throw it straight into the field. The "thrower-in" is allowed five seconds. If he holds it longer it shall go to the opponent. If any side persists in delaying the game, the umpire shall call a foul on them.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-The umpire shall be the judge of the men and shall note the fouls, and notify the referee when three consecutive fouls have been made.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-The referee shall be the judge of the ball and shall decide when the ball is in play, in-bounds, and to which side it belongs, and shall keep the time. He shall decide when a goal has been made and keep account of the goals with any other duties that are usually performed by a referee.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-The time shall be fifteen-minute halves, with five-minute rests between.</p> </h2>
<h2> <p>-The side making the most goals in that time shall be declared the winner. In the case of a draw, the game may, by agreement of the captains, be continued until another goal is made.</p> </h2>
<h1><center>THE PHILIPPINE BASKETBALL ASSOCIATION </H1>
<IMG SRC="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dd/Philippine_Basketball_Association_%28logo%29.svg/250px-Philippine_Basketball_Association_%28logo%29.svg.png" WIDTH="50%" HEIGHT="350" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H2> <P>The Philippine Basketball Association (PBA) is a men's professional basketball league in the Philippines composed of twelve company-branded franchised teams.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Founded in 1975, it is the first professional basketball league in Asia and is the second-oldest continuously operating professional basketball league in the world after North America's NBA.</P> </H2>

<H2> <P>The league played its first game at the Araneta Coliseum in Quezon City on April 9, 1975, and its regulations are a hybrid of rules from the NBA and FIBA.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> As of the 2022–23 season, the PBA season consists of three tournaments known as "conferences": the Philippine Cup, the Commissioner's Cup, and the Governors' Cup.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The Commissioner's and Governors' Cups allow each team to sign a single foreign player known as an "import".</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Meanwhile, the Philippine Cup is exclusive for Filipino players and is considered the most prestigious of the three conferences.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Although the three conferences have minor variations in format and rules, each consists of a single round-robin elimination round followed by playoffs to determine the champion.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The winners of the conference cups do not face each other at the end of the season to determine the season champion; instead, each conference champion team are considered PBA champions.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The achievement of a team winning all three conferences in a season is called the Grand Slam.</P> </H2>

<H2 <P>The San Miguel Beermen are the most successful team with a total of 29 championships, including a Grand Slam in 1989.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> They have also won the most titles in each of the current conferences: 10 Philippine Cups, 5 Commissioner's Cups, and 5 Governors' Cups.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Meanwhile, the defunct Crispa Redmanizers are the only team to have achieved two Grand Slams.</P> </H2>

<H2> <P>As of 2022–23, the PBA earned ?200 million in net revenue and had an average television audience of 4 million per game.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The PBA also has an official developmental league, the PBA D-League.</P> </H2>
<H1><CENTER>THE GAME RULES OF PBA</H1>
<IMG SRC="https://www.pba.com/sites/pba/files/2020-10/OFFICIAL_RULEBOOK_2.3_0.jpg" WIDTH="50%" HEIGHT="350" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H2> <P>The PBA uses its own rules for its games, independent from FIBA or the NBA.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Most non-professional leagues in the Philippines primarily use FIBA rules, so called "amateur rules", although recent professional leagues, such as the MPBL and PSL, have used FIBA rules for its games.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The Games and Amusements Board (GAB) has its rules for the size of the basketball court and equipment, which the PBA adapts.</P> </H2>

<H2> <P>Game rules have previously been predominantly influenced by the NBA, such as the rules on illegal defenses.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> After PBA players have been allowed to represent the Philippines in FIBA tournaments.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The league adopted a portion of the FIBA rules, including allowing zone defenses, so that the Philippine national team will not be disadvantaged in FIBA competitions.</P> </H2>
<H1><CENTER>FOUNDING OF THE PHILIPPINE ASSOCIATION</H1>\
<IMG SRC="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/74/First_PBA_logo.svg/150px-First_PBA_logo.svg.png" WIDTH="50%" HEIGHT="350" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H2> <P>The Philippine Basketball Association was founded when nine teams left the now-defunct Manila Industrial and Commercial Athletic Association (MICAA), which was tightly controlled by the Basketball Association of the Philippines (BAP), the FIBA-recognized national association at the time.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> With the BAP controlling the MICAA, the league was de jure amateur, as players were only paid allowances.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> This is much like what was done in other countries to circumvent the amateur requirement and to play in FIBA-sanctioned tournaments such as the Olympics.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> MICAA team owners were not pleased with how BAP (then led by Gonzalo "Lito" Puyat) were taking away their players to join the national team without consulting them first.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> On January 23, 1975, Mariwasa-Noritake Porcelainmakers' team owner, Emerson Coseteng, together with Carrier Weathermakers, Toyota Comets, Seven-Up Uncolas and Presto Ice Cream announced the formation of the PBA.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The Crispa Redmanizers, Royal Tru-Orange, Tanduay Distillery, and the U/Tex Weavers later joined the upcoming professional league.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Leopoldo Prieto, the coach for the Philippines at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, was appointed as the first commissioner and Coseteng was chosen as the first president of the league's Board of Governors.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The first game of the league was held at the Araneta Coliseum on April 9, 1975, featuring Mariwasa-Noritake and Concepcion Carrier.</P> </H2>
<H1><CENTER>THE RECORDS AND RIVALRIES OF PHILIPPINE BASKETBALL ASSOCIATION</H1>
<IMG SRC="https://images.gmanews.tv/webpics/2021/04/pba-logo_2021_04_20_21_37_39.jpg" WIDTH="50%" HEIGHT="350" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H2> <P>There are all-time records written in Philippine Basketball Association records, as well as distinctions like the PBA career scoring leaders, PBA 2,000 Assists Club, PBA 500 Three-Points Club, PBA 600 Most Games Club, and PBA Top 40 Rebounders.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Unlike other leagues, the PBA records of individual players combine both elimination round and playoff round statistics instead of placing them in separate categories.</P> </H2>

<H2> <P>The most famous matchup was the Crispa-Toyota rivalry of the 1970s.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Fans faithfully supported their favorite squads and appeared in the multitudes at the Araneta Coliseum, or wherever the archrivals had met.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> In those days, the players were very passionate. On one occasion, they engaged in a major brawl, leading to the arrest and detention of several players from both clubs at Fort Bonifacio.</P> </H2>

<H2> <P>The most heated rivalry in the PBA today is that of two teams representing the Ginebra franchise and the Purefoods franchise.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The rivalry is now commonly known as the Manila Clasico. It traces its roots on the original Añejo–Purefoods rivalry of the late 1980s to early 1990s.</P> </H2>

<H2> <P>Other short-lived or less intense rivalries include:</H2> </P>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Tanduay vs Ginebra (1986–1987 rivalry)</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Ginebra–Shell rivalry (1990s rivalry)</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Purefoods–Swift rivalry (1990s corporate rivalry)</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Añejo/Ginebra vs San Miguel (late-1980s to present rivalry)</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Ginebra/Gordon's Gin vs Alaska (late-1980s–2022)</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Alaska vs Purefoods (late-1980s–2022)</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Alaska vs San Miguel (late-1980s–2022)</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Red Bull vs. the San Miguel franchises (Barangay Ginebra, San Miguel and Purefoods, 2000–2007)</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Talk 'N Text/TNT vs. Petron/San Miguel (2010–present)</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Purefoods/San Mig Coffee/B-Meg/Star/Magnolia vs. Rain or Shine (2009–present, "New Age Rivalry or Kontrapelo")</P> </H2>
<H2> <P>&#9829;Ginebra vs. Meralco (2016–present)</P> </H2>

<H1><CENTER>LIST OF VENUES PLAYED BY THE PHILIPPINE BASKETBALL ASSOCIAION</H1>
<IMG SRC="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Mall_of_Asia_Arena_2019.jpg/170px-Mall_of_Asia_Arena_2019.jpg" WIDTH="50%" HEIGHT="350" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H2> <P>As teams do not represent geographic locales, the league itself rents venues for which it plays on.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> The PBA usually plays a doubleheader three times a week at the arenas in Metro Manila, and a game on Saturdays at the provinces, popularly known as "out-of-town" games.</P> </H2>

<H2> <P>Majority of games are being held at the Araneta Coliseum in Quezon City and the SM Mall of Asia Arena in Pasay.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> When both arenas are unavailable, the alternate venues are the Ynares Center in Antipolo, Rizal, PhilSports Arena in Pasig, and the Filoil EcoOil Centre in San Juan.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Occasionally, provincial games are hosted in selected venues throughout the country.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> Playoff games are usually held at venues in Metro Manila, most often at the Araneta Coliseum.</P> </H2> <H2> <P> However, recent incentives to promote the league throughout the country have resulted in out-of-town playoff games.</P> </H2>

<H2> <P>The league has also played several times outside the Philippines, the majority in Dubai where there is a large Filipino community.</P> </H2>
